title: Cat. 37  Sketch of Maori Woman and Child (recto), Sketch of Man with a Hat and Fragment of Woman’s Shoulder (verso), 1891/93
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Sketch of Maori Woman and Child (recto), Sketch of Man with a Hat and Fragment of Woman’s Shoulder (verso, fig. 37.1)  
1891/93  
Pen and brown ink (originally purple), with touches of graphite (recto); graphite (verso); on cream wove irregularly shaped paper, discolored to tan (removed from a sketchbook); 163 × 43 mm (max.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Edward McCormick Blair, 2002.234R/V

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Gauguin used sketchbooks to record his many observations of daily life in Tahiti. While five sketchbooks remain bound, others were taken apart, their sheets removed from their bindings and often cut down into smaller sheets. Sketch of Maori Woman and Child is certainly one of these many sheets. In this case, it is likely that Gauguin removed the sheet from a sketchbook and cut it down to follow the contours of the figures. Two additional sheets in the Art Institute’s collection have been similarly cut down into smaller sheets (cats. 36 and 38). On the verso of this sketch there are two small partial figural sketches.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 37.2).

Three drawings in the Art Institute’s collection, Head of a Tahitian Woman (cat. 36), Tahitian Eve (cat. 38), and this sheet, bear a striking similarity to each other. All are drawn on the same type of paper, all have been trimmed to some degree, and all are drawn in ink that was originally purple. This sheet, however, is irregularly cut to conform to the shape of the sketch. Another sketch, Hina (Maori Woman Stylized as an Idol) (fig. 37.3), appears to derive from the same moment; it is cut in a similar manner and was documented early in the twentieth century as being drawn with pen and purple ink. The ink used for the three Chicago sketches is identical, the pigment particles disperse in the same way, and the ink has faded in like manner. In this drawing, lighter passages of ink appear pale yellow under magnification, with flecks of black-pigment particles sparsely dispersed in the drawn lines, while in darker areas, the flecks of black pigment are more prominent and gather together (fig. 37.4).

XRF analysis of the ink has confirmed the presence of chromium, a major component in the manufacture of chrome logwood ink. Bottled chrome logwood inks could be purchased in a variety of tones that ranged from bright purple to reddish mauve, and brownish purple to brownish black, depending upon the amount of metal salts, such as iron, added. Higher metal-salt content would produce darker and blacker inks. The nature of the logwood dye used in the manufacture of the inks would determine the purple hue that could be obtained. However, the inherent instability of chrome logwood inks often results in the complete loss of their purple hues, as has happened in this drawing.

Only minimal amounts of iron are present here, indicative of an ink formulation that was likely quite purple in tone. Despite the low levels of iron detected, the chromium to iron ratio does vary depending on the intensity of the ink in the analyzed areas. This helps to confirm the presence of two different inks: a pale ink with low levels of chromium and a dark one with higher chromium levels. Early chroniclers of Gauguin’s drawings often referenced a range of colored inks from violette (purple) to bleue (blue) to black. Present-day viewers may find it difficult to imagine what Gauguin’s ink sketches would have looked like as they first emerged from a pen loaded with purple ink. A digital recolorization based on the study of unfaded ink samples provides a hypothetical rendering (fig. 37.5).

Touches of graphite were used to reinforce the Maori woman’s breasts, her proper left shoulder, arm and cupped hand, and proper right forearm. These lines would have been much less prominent when drawn over unfaded purple ink. Today, the graphite lines add a silvery gray tone to the composition that does not harmonize with the warm tones that surround them and detracts from the legibility of the drawing.

On the verso there is a sketch of a standing male figure in the upper left and a kneeling figure along the bottom. These forms were cropped when the sheet was cut into its present shape.

The paper is typical of a type that was often bound into Gauguin’s sketchbooks—poor-quality, thin, moderately sized, machine-made stock conducive to working in inks and watercolors, or with charcoal, chalk, crayon, and graphite. This sheet was cut down along all of its edges, yet its physical characteristics, combined with its unusual size, reveal that it too is a page removed from a sketchbook.

The sheet is identical in type to that used for Head of a Tahitian Woman (cat. 36) and Tahitian Eve (cat. 38), pages that were also likely removed from a disassembled sketchbook dating from Gauguin’s first Tahitian voyage in 1891–93. Although the sheets upon which all of the sketches were drawn suffered significant discoloration due to overexposure to light, the sheets of paper are of a similar tone in areas that were protected from light; they have the same surface texture, weight, and wove paper mold characteristics. In them, the paper fibers display the same mesh pattern from the mold and appear evenly dispersed throughout when viewed in transmitted light. Also, under ultraviolet light the sheets fluoresce dull yellow, a characteristic that is common to a number of disbound sketchbook sheets and indicative of the aged gelatin sizing in the paper.

163 × 43 mm (max.)

Extensive examination and treatment was carried out in 2002. As part of this campaign, a secondary support was removed, which revealed the verso of this fragmentary sketchbook sheet. Even through the secondary support, numerous abrasions were observed and were likely the reason the small, vulnerable sheet was initially mounted to a backing. After the backing was removed, the abraded areas were reinforced with Japanese paper fibers, and small edge tears were mended.

The drawing is in sound, stable condition. The inks remain much faded and embrittled. Conservation treatment rendered the sheet brighter and increased overall contrast in the composition, making it more legible. In raking light, abraded areas appear more dimensional on the verso and paper deformations more pronounced on the recto. In transmitted light, the uneven paper thickness is visible. Although the presence of these abrasions make it likely that the small sheet was initially mounted to provide structural support, it was decided that a new backing that would obscure the fragmentary sketches on the verso was not necessary.  
Harriet K. Stratis with scientific analyses by Céline Daher

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Possibly sold to Victor Segalen (1878–1919) at the public auction of the artist’s belongings upon his death, Papeete, Tahiti, Sept. 2, 1903.

Ambroise Vollard (1866–1939), Paris by 1927.

Galerie Marcel Guiot (1893–1977), Paris, by 1942.

M. Yves Renaudin, Paris.

Sold through Alice Adam Ltd., Chicago, to Edward McCormick Blair (1915–2010), Chicago, Apr. 1986.

Given by Edward McCormick Blair to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Paris, Galerie Marcel Guiot, Documents Tahiti, May 15–June 13, 1942, cat. 56.

Paris, Galerie Charpentier, Cent oeuvres de Gauguin, 1960, cat. 167.

Munich, Haus der Kunst, Paul Gauguin, Apr. 1–May 29, 1960, cat. 132.

Tokyo, Grand Magasin Seibu, Paul Gauguin, Aug. 23–Sept. 30, 1969, cat. 71 (ill.); Kyoto, National Museum of Modern Art, Oct. 5–Nov. 7, 1969; Fukuoka, Cultural Center of Fukuoka Prefecture, Nov. 13–Dec. 7, 1969.

Art Institute of Chicago, Intimate Encounters: Paul Gauguin and the South Pacific; The Edward McCormick Blair Collection, Sept. 6, 2003–Jan. 11, 2004, cat. 11.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Exposition Gauguin: Aquarelles, monotypes, dessins, preface by Marcel Guérin, exh. cat. (Galerie Marcel Guiot, 1942), p. 32, cat. 56.

Lettres de Gauguin à sa femme et à ses amis, ed. Maurice Malingue (B. Grasset, 1946), p. 176, pl. 23 (ill.).

Haus der Kunst, Paul Gauguin, exh. cat. (Ausstellungsleitung München e.V. Haus der Kunst, 1960), p. 23, cat. 132.

Raymond Nacenta, Cent oeuvres de Gauguin, exh. cat. (Galerie Charpentier, 1960), cat. 167.

Yoshiaki Inui, Kenji Suzuki, and Takeo Uchiyama, Paul Gauguin, exh. cat. (Shimbun, 1969), cat. 71 (ill.).

Art Institute of Chicago, Intimate Encounters: Paul Gauguin and the South Pacific; The Edward McCormick Blair Collection, exhibition brochure (Art Institute of Chicago, 2003), cat. 11.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Inscribed, lower right, in graphite: N 11 [double underlined]

The nature of the media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm). The ink was identifed by XRF.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">This drawing was in Gauguin’s portfolio Documents Tahiti: 1891, 1892, 1893, which remained together in the possession of Ambroise Vollard until it was dispersed at the 1942 Galerie Marcel Guiot sale (see Provenance).

Using the toolbar at the bottom right, any two images of the artwork may be selected for comparison by clicking the layers icon to the right of the slider bar. The slider bar may be moved to transition back and forth between the two chosen images. Where annotations are available the jagged-line icon brings up a list of available annotations, or colored lines that show the significant features visible in each image, which may be turned on or off in any combination. For example, the red annotation lines, associated with the natural-light image, trace some of the artwork’s key compositional features. When overlaid onto a technical image (X-ray, raking light, ultraviolet, etc.), the red outlines help the viewer to better observe how features in the technical image relate to or diverge from the artwork as seen with the naked eye. (When annotations are turned on, a legend appears in the upper right showing each color and its associated image type.) The circular-arrow icon returns the image to the default settings (natural light, full-image view, natural-light [red] annotation on). The four-arrow icon toggles between the view of the image in the page and a full-screen view of the image. In the upper right corner, the vertical slider bar may be moved to zoom into or out of the image; different parts of the image can be accessed by clicking and dragging within the image itself. The icon in the upper left corner opens a small view of the full image, within which a red box indicates the portion of the overall image being viewed when zooming is enabled.

In the list of illustrations the work is described as “Dessin a la plume, a l’encre violette” (“Drawing in pen, in purple ink”). Reproduced in Lettres de Gauguin à sa femme et à ses amis, ed. Maurice Malingue (B. Grasset, 1946), opposite p. 176, pl. 22.

The Chicago drawing, plate 23, opposite page 177, is also listed as “Drawing in pen, in purple ink.” Hina (Woman Stylized as a Maori Idol) also appears in Exposition Gauguin: Aquarelles, monotypes, dessins, preface by Marcel Guérin, exh. cat.(Galerie Marcel Guiot, 1942), as no. 56, in which it is also described as drawn in pen and purple ink (“dessin a la plume, a l’encre violette”).

I am grateful to Céline Daher for her XRF analysis and identification of chrome logwood ink. Céline Daher, XRF analytical results summary, Nov. 2015, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago. See also Marjorie Shelley, “Technical Studies: Observations on the Drawing Materials Used by Van Gogh in Provence,” with scientific analyses by Silvia A. Centeno, in Colta Ives, Susan Alyson Stein, Srjaar van Heugten, and Marije Vellekoop, Van Gogh: The Drawings (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York/Van Gogh Museum/Yale University Press, 2005), pp. 348–59, for her study and analysis of the inks used by Van Gogh, especially his use of logwood inks. See also Han Neeval, Maarten van Bommel, Marje Vellekoop, and Nico Lingbeek, “Non-Invasive Identification of Van Gogh’s Drawing Inks,” in ICOM Committee for Conservation, 15th Triennial Conference New Delhi, Sept. 22–26, 2008: Preprints, vol. 1, ed. Janet Bridgland (Allied Publishers Pvt., 2008), pp. 980–86. To clarify his working practice, the brown and purple inks on forty-two drawings executed by Van Gogh during the period 1878–90 were identified using fiber-optic reflectance spectroscopy (FORS). Chrome logwood ink was identified.

A number of works drawn in pen and purple ink are listed in the exhibition catalogue Exposition Gauguin: Aquarelles, monotypes, dessins, preface by Marcel Guérin, exh. cat. (Galerie Marcel Guiot, 1942). Chicago’s Maori Woman and Her Child (cat. 37) is number 55 in the checklist; a second drawing, entitled Hina (Maori Woman Stylized as an Idol), is number 56. The latter is reproduced in Letttres de Gauguin à sa femme et à ses amis, ed. Maurice Malingue (B. Grasset, 1946), opposite p. 176, pl. 22, and in the list of illustrations is described as “Dessin a la plume, a l’encre violette” (“Drawing in pen, in purple ink”). The Chicago drawing (cat. 37), plate 23, opposite page 177 in the Malingue edition, is also described as “drawing in pen, in purple ink.”

Kristi Dahm, condition report, treatment record and photographic documentation, Nov. 2002, conservation object file, Department of Print and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

According to Richard S. Field, Paul Gauguin: Monotypes, exh. cat. (Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1973), p. 25. This drawing was part of Gauguin’s portfolio, Documents Tahiti: 1891, 1892, 1893, which remained together until it was dispersed at the 1942 Galerie Marcel Guiot sale. Due to the contents of the portfolio, which contained many of Gauguin’s later monotypes from 1899 or 1900, Field assumes this was part of the artist’s estate at the time of his death. See also Galerie Marcel Guiot, Exposition Gauguin: Aquarelles, monotypes, dessins, preface by Marcel Guérin, exh. cat. (Galerie Marcel Guiot, 1942), p. 32, cat. 56.

According to Marcel Guérin, Vollard bought a portfolio of drawings, watercolors, and monotypes in a portfolio with the date 1891, 1892, 1893; see Marcel Guérin, L’oeuvre gravé de Gauguin (H. Floury, 1927; Alan Wofsy Fine Arts, 1980), p. xxix. In the view of Richard Field, this portfolio was in the collection of Ambroise Vollard and presented to Marcel Guiot in around 1942, presumably from Vollard’s estate; Richard S. Field, Paul Gauguin: Monotypes, exh. cat. (Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1973), p. 25. This drawing was part of Gauguin’s portfolio, Documents Tahiti: 1891, 1892, 1893, which remained together until it was dispersed at the 1942 Galerie Marcel Guiot sale. See Galerie Marcel Guiot, Exposition Gauguin: Aquarelles, monotypes, dessins, preface by Marcel Guérin, exh. cat. (Galerie Marcel Guiot, 1942), p. 32, cat. 56.

According to Galerie Marcel Guiot, Exposition Gauguin: Aquarelles, monotypes, dessins, preface by Marcel Guérin, exh. cat. (Galerie Marcel Guiot, 1942), p. 32, cat. 56, this drawing was part of Gauguin’s portfolio Documents Tahiti: 1891, 1892, 1893 that was dispersed at this sale.

According to Haus der Kunst, Paul Gauguin, exh. cat. (Ausstellungsleitung München e.V. Haus der Kunst, 1960), p. 23, cat. 132. See also Yoshiaki Inui, Kenji Suzuki, and Takeo Uchiyama, Paul Gauguin, exh. cat. (Shimbun, 1969), cat. 71 (ill.).

According to Alice Adam Ltd., Chicago, invoice addressed to Edward Blair, Sr., Apr. 24, 1986. Possibly from the sale a month earlier at Nouveau Drouot, Paris, Importants tableaux modernes, sale cat. (Drouot, Mar. 21, 1986), lot 36 (ill.).
